column3: 1)	" Wow
column4: in 90 seconds? I can't clear my throat in 90 seconds. Jim
column5: Bob Dole and myself do not see Al Gore and Bill Clinton as our enemy. We see them as our opponents. This is the greatest democracy in the world. People are watching not only throughout this country
column6: but all over the world as to how this democracy can function with civility and respect
column7: and decency and integrity. Bob Dole
column8: um
column9: is one of those men who served in the United States Senate
column10: his public life is a public record. He fought on the battlefield. He has worked with Democrats and Republicans. In my opinion
column11: it is beneath Bob Dole to go after anyone personally. Clearly
column12: Abraham Lincoln put it best when he said you serve your party best by serving the nation first. And I can't think of a better way of serving this nation in 1996 than by electing Bob Dole as the President of the United States of America. These issues are fully capable of being understood and reflected upon by the American people. This is a democracy in which we have the freest press and the greatest First Amendment rights in the history of mankind. And Bob and I respect that. These issues will be aired
column13: but they'll be aired with dignity and respect
column14: and
column15: ultimately
column16: leave it to the American people to make up their minds about who should be the leader of this country into the 21st Century.

column2: Mr. Lehrer. And I would like to thank the people of St. Petersburg for being such wonderful hosts. My family and I are very glad to be here and I would like to thank Jack Kemp for the answer that he just gave. I think we have an opportunity tonight to have a positive debate about this country's future. I'd like to start by offering you a deal
column3: Jack. If you won't use any football stories
column4: I won't tell any of my warm and humorous stories about chlorofluorocarbon abatement.

column1: It's a deal. I can't even pronounce it.
What I do want to talk about tonight is Bill Clinton's positive plan for America's future. We have a plan to balance the budget while protecting Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: education and the environment. Creating millions of new jobs
column4: including one million new jobs in America's inner cities. I'm excited about the chance to talk about this plan and even more excited about the chance to work on it
column5: if you
column6: the people of this country
column7: will give Bill Clinton and me the privilege of doing so for four more years.

column1: I really got only two differences with Bill Clinton -- Â President Clinton and Mr. Gore
column2: foreign policy and domestic policy. Our foreign policy is ambivalent
column3: confusing
column4: it is sending strong signals to the wrong people
column5: and we have learned over the years that weakness is provocative
column6: but domestic economy is not doing what it can do. This President believes we are at our capacity. Bob Dole and I believe we can do a lot better. It is about the potential of the American people to lift themselves up and not have their lives controlled by the United States Government and Washington.

column1: The differences are very clear. We have a positive plan based on three principles. We want to provide opportunity for all Americans. We insist on responsibility being accepted in turn by everyone
column2: and we want to strengthen our communities and their ability to support families and individuals in our common effort to create a bright future. Here's how we plan to do that: We have a balanced budget plan that has targeted tax cuts for middle-income families. We've already given tax cuts to 15 million of the hardest pressed working families in America. Our plan for the next four years features a $1
column3: 500 tax credit
column4: called a Hope Scholarship
column5: for tuition at community college
column6: junior college or college. A $10
column7: 000 tax deduction for college tuition for those who go further
column8: so that
column9: in essence
column10: no American family will ever be taxed on the money they spend for college tuition. Also
column11: tax relief for first-time home buyers
column12: tax encouragement for savings and help in paying health care expenses
column13: and a tax break
column14: actually
column15: the elimination of capital gains taxes on the -- on the profits from the sale of a home. All of this is within a balanced budget plan
column16: which protects Medicare
column17: Medicaid
column18: education and the environment.

column2: this economy is overtaxed
column3: overregulated
column4: too many people suing each other
column5: there's too much litigation. Our education is not up to the standards that the American family and the American people want for their children. And
column6: clearly
column7: the welfare system is a disgrace to our Judeo-Christian principles. It is not the values of the poor that should be called into question
column8: it is the values of the welfare system from Washington and uh that prevent people from climbing out of poverty. Our biggest debate with this administration on domestic policy is that they think we're at our fullest capacity
column9: that weâ€™ve reached our potential and 2.5 percent growth is enough for America. Frankly
column10: that is not good enough for this country. We can not just run the clock out on the 20th Century. It
column11: clearly
column12: we need to lower the tax rate across the board on working and saving and investing. I know my friend
column13: Al
column14: will suggest that is trickle-down economics. Well
column15: Al
column16: if it's trickle-down economics
column17: ask Van Woods
column18: a young entrepreneur who owns a restaurant in Harlem
column19: if it's trickle down. He said he would hire 60 more people if we cut the Capital Gains Tax.

column1: I talked about our positive agenda for the future a moment ago. Your original answer was about the contrast. The plan from Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp is a risky
column2: $550-billion tax scheme that actually raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest pressed working families. It would blow a hole in the deficit
column3: cause much deeper cuts in Medicare
column4: Medicaid
column5: education and the environment and knock our economy off track
column6: raising interest rates
column7: mortgage rates and car payments. We stopped that plan before. We will stop it again. We want a positive plan for growth and more jobs.

column2: this is a perfect example. Bob Dole and I want to cut the tax rates across the board on each and every American
column3: working
column4: saving
column5: investing and taking risks in America. All wealth is created
column6: and all growth is generated by risk-taking entrepreneurs. The tax rate on capital in America is way too high. It's too high on the family and it's particularly too high on working men and women. The average family in America
column7: at median level of income
column8: probably is spending 25 to 26 percent of their income sent to the federal government. That's more than shelter
column9: food
column10: clothing
column11: and energy. That's just not right. When I was growing up in Los Angeles
column12: my parents were a one working family
column13: one breadwinner per family was all that was necessary. Now if a woman wants to go to work or a man wants to go to work
column14: it ought to be their choice
column15: not the choice of the Washington
column16: D.C. establishment. Bill Clinton
column17: the President
column18: and Al Gore
column19: suggest that they'll give us a tax cut
column20: but only if we do exactly what they want us to do. That isn't America. That's social engineering. The tax code should reflect our values in a Judeo-Christian sense
column22: honesty and integrity and contracts and property and investment and savings should be rewarded
column23: and Bob Dole and Jack Kemp are not only going to cut the tax rates across the board and lower the Capital Gain Tax. I'll be glad to talk about it a little later
column24: because there's not enough time
column25: but we are going to repeal the 83-year-old code and replace the seven and a half million words with a flatter
column26: fairer
column27: simpler code that will take this country roaring in the 21st Century.

column1: This risky tax scheme would blow a hole in the deficit. You don't have to take my word for it. ""Time
column2: ""Newsweek
column3: ""U.S. News & World Report
column4: ""Business Week
column5: 83 percent of hundreds of economists in a random survey just recently all said it would blow a hole in the deficit. There's another feature I would like to hear Mr. Kemp speak about. Just before he joined Senator Dole on the ticket
column6: he said that the plan -- the part of the plan that raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest working families in America was unconscionable
column7: that means it's wrong and it shouldn't happen. I agree
column8: it is still part of the plan. We believe that taxes should not be increased on those families. We have a plan to cut taxes on middle income families within a balanced budget plan
column9: eliminating the deficit and protecting Medicare
column10: Medicaid
column11: education and the environment.

column1: Every time this country in the 20th Century has cut tax rates across the board
column2: revenues went up
column3: the economy grew
column4: and I am surprised at this point in his career that Vice President Gore and the President cannot understand that you get more revenue from a bigger pie
column5: and clearly
column6: creating more jobs reduces the social welfare drain
column7: clearly makes more opportunity for capital to be invested in our inner cities. And frankly
column8: Al
column9: we shouldn't just tinker with the Capital Gain Tax
column10: we should eliminate it in the inner cities of America to put capital to work to make democratic capitalism and jobs available in our inner cities of the United States.

column8: um
column9: is one of those men who served in the United States Senate
column10: his public life is a public record. He fought on the battlefield. He has worked with Democrats and Republicans. In my opinion
column11: it is beneath Bob Dole to go after anyone personally. Clearly
column12: Abraham Lincoln put it best when he said you serve your party best by serving the nation first. And I can't think of a better way of serving this nation in 1996 than by electing Bob Dole as the President of the United States of America. These issues are fully capable of being understood and reflected upon by the American people. This is a democracy in which we have the freest press and the greatest First Amendment rights in the history of mankind. And Bob and I respect that. These issues will be aired
column13: but they'll be aired with dignity and respect
column14: and
column15: ultimately
column16: leave it to the American people to make up their minds about who should be the leader of this country into the 21st Century.

column2: Mr. Lehrer. And I would like to thank the people of St. Petersburg for being such wonderful hosts. My family and I are very glad to be here and I would like to thank Jack Kemp for the answer that he just gave. I think we have an opportunity tonight to have a positive debate about this country's future. I'd like to start by offering you a deal
column3: Jack. If you won't use any football stories
column4: I won't tell any of my warm and humorous stories about chlorofluorocarbon abatement.

column1: It's a deal. I can't even pronounce it.
What I do want to talk about tonight is Bill Clinton's positive plan for America's future. We have a plan to balance the budget while protecting Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: education and the environment. Creating millions of new jobs
column4: including one million new jobs in America's inner cities. I'm excited about the chance to talk about this plan and even more excited about the chance to work on it
column5: if you
column6: the people of this country
column7: will give Bill Clinton and me the privilege of doing so for four more years.

column1: I really got only two differences with Bill Clinton -- Â President Clinton and Mr. Gore
column2: foreign policy and domestic policy. Our foreign policy is ambivalent
column3: confusing
column4: it is sending strong signals to the wrong people
column5: and we have learned over the years that weakness is provocative
column6: but domestic economy is not doing what it can do. This President believes we are at our capacity. Bob Dole and I believe we can do a lot better. It is about the potential of the American people to lift themselves up and not have their lives controlled by the United States Government and Washington.

column1: The differences are very clear. We have a positive plan based on three principles. We want to provide opportunity for all Americans. We insist on responsibility being accepted in turn by everyone
column2: and we want to strengthen our communities and their ability to support families and individuals in our common effort to create a bright future. Here's how we plan to do that: We have a balanced budget plan that has targeted tax cuts for middle-income families. We've already given tax cuts to 15 million of the hardest pressed working families in America. Our plan for the next four years features a $1
column3: 500 tax credit
column4: called a Hope Scholarship
column5: for tuition at community college
column6: junior college or college. A $10
column7: 000 tax deduction for college tuition for those who go further
column8: so that
column9: in essence
column10: no American family will ever be taxed on the money they spend for college tuition. Also
column11: tax relief for first-time home buyers
column12: tax encouragement for savings and help in paying health care expenses
column13: and a tax break
column14: actually
column15: the elimination of capital gains taxes on the -- on the profits from the sale of a home. All of this is within a balanced budget plan
column16: which protects Medicare
column17: Medicaid
column18: education and the environment.

column2: this economy is overtaxed
column3: overregulated
column4: too many people suing each other
column5: there's too much litigation. Our education is not up to the standards that the American family and the American people want for their children. And
column6: clearly
column7: the welfare system is a disgrace to our Judeo-Christian principles. It is not the values of the poor that should be called into question
column8: it is the values of the welfare system from Washington and uh that prevent people from climbing out of poverty. Our biggest debate with this administration on domestic policy is that they think we're at our fullest capacity
column9: that weâ€™ve reached our potential and 2.5 percent growth is enough for America. Frankly
column10: that is not good enough for this country. We can not just run the clock out on the 20th Century. It
column11: clearly
column12: we need to lower the tax rate across the board on working and saving and investing. I know my friend
column13: Al
column14: will suggest that is trickle-down economics. Well
column15: Al
column16: if it's trickle-down economics
column17: ask Van Woods
column18: a young entrepreneur who owns a restaurant in Harlem
column19: if it's trickle down. He said he would hire 60 more people if we cut the Capital Gains Tax.

column1: I talked about our positive agenda for the future a moment ago. Your original answer was about the contrast. The plan from Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp is a risky
column2: $550-billion tax scheme that actually raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest pressed working families. It would blow a hole in the deficit
column3: cause much deeper cuts in Medicare
column4: Medicaid
column5: education and the environment and knock our economy off track
column6: raising interest rates
column7: mortgage rates and car payments. We stopped that plan before. We will stop it again. We want a positive plan for growth and more jobs.

column2: this is a perfect example. Bob Dole and I want to cut the tax rates across the board on each and every American
column3: working
column4: saving
column5: investing and taking risks in America. All wealth is created
column6: and all growth is generated by risk-taking entrepreneurs. The tax rate on capital in America is way too high. It's too high on the family and it's particularly too high on working men and women. The average family in America
column7: at median level of income
column8: probably is spending 25 to 26 percent of their income sent to the federal government. That's more than shelter
column9: food
column10: clothing
column11: and energy. That's just not right. When I was growing up in Los Angeles
column12: my parents were a one working family
column13: one breadwinner per family was all that was necessary. Now if a woman wants to go to work or a man wants to go to work
column14: it ought to be their choice
column15: not the choice of the Washington

column18: and Al Gore

column1: This risky tax scheme would blow a hole in the deficit. You don't have to take my word for it. ""Time

column5: 83 percent of hundreds of economists in a random survey just recently all said it would blow a hole in the deficit. There's another feature I would like to hear Mr. Kemp speak about. Just before he joined Senator Dole on the ticket

column7: that means it's wrong and it shouldn't happen. I agree

column1: Every time this country in the 20th Century has cut tax rates across the board

This is a democracy in which we have the freest press and the greatest First Amendment rights in the history of mankind. And Bob and I respect that. These issues will be aired
column13: but they'll be aired with dignity and respect
column14: and
column15: ultimately
column16: leave it to the American people to make up their minds about who should be the leader of this country into the 21st Century.

column2: Mr. Lehrer. And I would like to thank the people of St. Petersburg for being such wonderful hosts. My family and I are very glad to be here and I would like to thank Jack Kemp for the answer that he just gave. I think we have an opportunity tonight to have a positive debate about this country's future. I'd like to start by offering you a deal
column3: Jack. If you won't use any football stories
column4: I won't tell any of my warm and humorous stories about chlorofluorocarbon abatement.

column1: It's a deal. I can't even pronounce it.
What I do want to talk about tonight is Bill Clinton's positive plan for America's future. We have a plan to balance the budget while protecting Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: education and the environment. Creating millions of new jobs
column4: including one million new jobs in America's inner cities. I'm excited about the chance to talk about this plan and even more excited about the chance to work on it
column5: if you
column6: the people of this country
column7: will give Bill Clinton and me the privilege of doing so for four more years.

column1: I really got only two differences with Bill Clinton -- Â President Clinton and Mr. Gore
column2: foreign policy and domestic policy. Our foreign policy is ambivalent
column3: confusing
column4: it is sending strong signals to the wrong people
column5: and we have learned over the years that weakness is provocative
column6: but domestic economy is not doing what it can do. This President believes we are at our capacity. Bob Dole and I believe we can do a lot better. It is about the potential of the American people to lift themselves up and not have their lives controlled by the United States Government and Washington.

column1: The differences are very clear. We have a positive plan based on three principles. We want to provide opportunity for all Americans. We insist on responsibility being accepted in turn by everyone
column2: and we want to strengthen our communities and their ability to support families and individuals in our common effort to create a bright future. Here's how we plan to do that: We have a balanced budget plan that has targeted tax cuts for middle-income families. We've already given tax cuts to 15 million of the hardest pressed working families in America. Our plan for the next four years features a $1
column3: 500 tax credit
column4: called a Hope Scholarship
column5: for tuition at community college
column6: junior college or college. A $10
column7: 000 tax deduction for college tuition for those who go further
column8: so that
column9: in essence
column10: no American family will ever be taxed on the money they spend for college tuition. Also
column11: tax relief for first-time home buyers
column12: tax encouragement for savings and help in paying health care expenses
column13: and a tax break
column14: actually
column15: the elimination of capital gains taxes on the -- on the profits from the sale of a home. All of this is within a balanced budget plan
column16: which protects Medicare
column17: Medicaid
column18: education and the environment.

column2: this economy is overtaxed
column3: overregulated

column6: clearly

column8: it is the values of the welfare system from Washington and uh that prevent people from climbing out of poverty. Our biggest debate with this administration on domestic policy is that they think we're at our fullest capacity
column9: that weâ€™ve reached our potential and 2.5 percent growth is enough for America. Frankly
column10: that is not good enough for this country. We can not just run the clock out on the 20th Century. It

column4: Medicaid

column6: raising interest rates

column7: at median level of income

column2: Mr. Lehrer. And I would like to thank the people of St. Petersburg for being such wonderful hosts. My family and I are very glad to be here and I would like to thank Jack Kemp for the answer that he just gave. I think we have an opportunity tonight to have a positive debate about this country's future. I'd like to start by offering you a deal
column3: Jack. If you won't use any football stories
column4: I won't tell any of my warm and humorous stories about chlorofluorocarbon abatement.

column1: It's a deal. I can't even pronounce it.
What I do want to talk about tonight is Bill Clinton's positive plan for America's future. We have a plan to balance the budget while protecting Medicare
column2: Medicaid
column3: education and the environment. Creating millions of new jobs
column4: including one million new jobs in America's inner cities. I'm excited about the chance to talk about this plan and even more excited about the chance to work on it
column5: if you
column6: the people of this country
column7: will give Bill Clinton and me the privilege of doing so for four more years.

column1: I really got only two differences with Bill Clinton -- Â President Clinton and Mr. Gore
column2: foreign policy and domestic policy. Our foreign policy is ambivalent
column3: confusing
column4: it is sending strong signals to the wrong people
column5: and we have learned over the years that weakness is provocative
column6: but domestic economy is not doing what it can do. This President believes we are at our capacity. Bob Dole and I believe we can do a lot better. It is about the potential of the American people to lift themselves up and not have their lives controlled by the United States Government and Washington.

column1: The differences are very clear. We have a positive plan based on three principles. We want to provide opportunity for all Americans. We insist on responsibility being accepted in turn by everyone
column2: and we want to strengthen our communities and their ability to support families and individuals in our common effort to create a bright future. Here's how we plan to do that: We have a balanced budget plan that has targeted tax cuts for middle-income families. We've already given tax cuts to 15 million of the hardest pressed working families in America. Our plan for the next four years features a $1
column3: 500 tax credit
column4: called a Hope Scholarship
column5: for tuition at community college

column7: 000 tax deduction for college tuition for those who go further
column8: so that

column12: tax encouragement for savings and help in paying health care expenses
column13: and a tax break
column14: actually
column15: the elimination of capital gains taxes on the -- on the profits from the sale of a home. All of this is within a balanced budget plan
column16: which protects Medicare

column18: education and the environment.

column3: overregulated

column8: it is the values of the welfare system from Washington and uh that prevent people from climbing out of poverty. Our biggest debate with this administration on domestic policy is that they think we're at our fullest capacity

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 10)	" Thank you
column4: Jim and thanks to the people of St. Petersburg for a fantastic hospitality and my friend
column5: Al Gore
column6: for a vigorous debate. I think this is the most exciting time in the history of the world to be alive. We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history. We have defeated in this system of ours fascism
column7: Nazism
column8: communism
column9: socialism is defunct or debunked around the world
column10: the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century
column11: indeed the next millennium. Can we
column12: in America
column13: make the world's greatest liberal democracy
column14: this democratic experiment in private property
column15: limited government
column16: the rule of law
column17: respect for families and traditional Judeo-Christian values work
column18: so it can be a blessing to our country and a blessing to the rest of the world? With all due respect to this administration
column19: they've got a foreign policy in disarray. They have a lack of credibility around the world. Weakness
column20: I said earlier
column22: this economy is not performing up to the standards that we would expect from this great nation going into the most exciting global economy the world has ever known. There's something amiss. Our culture seems to be weakening all around us. Families are under tremendous pressure. People do not -- do not feel safe in their homes. A mother doesn't feel safe sending her child to school. Our schools are not educating. It's not the problem of the teachers. They are overworked and my daughter will tell you
column23: they are underpaid and we know that
column24: they need to be empowered. We need to reform education. We need to reform welfare. We need to reform litigation and regulation. And we certainly need to reform this tax code that is a product of this terrible century of war and recession and inflations. It can be done. We need somebody who understands the potential of the American people
column25: who are not just doing well for ourselves
column26: we need to do well for the rest of the world
column27: because they're looking at us. And we need to make it work in every neighborhood and community in America and for every family
column28: so that no one as Bob Dole said in his San Diego acceptance speech is left behind. Bob Dole
column30: is a man of courage
column32: a man who crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in 1945 to save a wounded brethren. The bible says no greater love hath a man than he gave his life. Well
column35: he'd been through the valley of the shadow and he as Commander-in-Chief can take this country with the courage of Churchill. The principles of Lincoln and the indefatigable optimism and spirit that this nation expects from its Commander-in-Chief and the next President of the United States

column2: Mr. Lehrer. Thanks again to the people of St. Petersburg and thanks again to Jack Kemp. I have enormous respect for Jack Kemp and for Bob Dole. They're good men. I don't agree with their plan. I've tried to make that clear tonight. And one reason I've tried to make it clear is that in just 27 days
column3: the United States of America has an important choice to make. Between two approaches to the future of this country. We have a plan that will create millions more jobs
column4: bring the deficits down further and balance the budget
column5: while protecting Medicare
column6: protecting Medicaid
column7: protecting and preserving the environment
column8: our air
column9: our water
column10: the Everglades
column11: the Tongas
column12: the Mojave Desert in California
column13: the Utah-Red Rocks area
column14: all of which have been protected by President Bill Clinton. We also have a plan to expand access to education. There's a family in the audience tonight
column15: the McNeil family
column16: who lives right here in St. Petersburg. Both parents are teachers
column17: they're not rich in money
column18: but they have strong values and they value education. They're oldest son is a freshman at St. Petersburg Junior High -- Junior College. Their younger son
column19: Roderick
column20: is a sophomore in the same high school that Don McNeil teaches at. Roderick is concerned that he may not be able to get the tuition he needs to go to college when the time comes. Our plan gives a $1500 tax credit to make that junior college essentially free. And a $10
column21: 000 tax deduction to make it so that no American family
column22: or almost no family
column23: will have to pay taxes on the money they pay for college tuition. This plan also gives tax breaks on the sale of a home
column24: up to $500
column25: 000 in profit tax free. It gives the new break for first-time home buyers
column26: and
column27: again
column28: all in the context of a balanced budget. We have seen progress during the last four years because policies like these have been working. This risky scheme that I've described tonight has been said by many objective observers to not add up
column29: it would be a serious risk. Our plan
column30: by contrast
column31: has been working and will work more. We want to build a bridge to the 21st Century and we want it to be strong enough and broad enough for all families to cross and we want it to lead to a brighter future for America
column32: 'cause our best days are ahead.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 2)	" Yes. President Clinton addressed this issue when he said
column4: ""Mend it
column5: don't end it."" Diversity is a great strength in America. Look around the world at other places where they have not paid attention to the necessity of promoting harmony of
column6: between different ethnic
column7: racial and religious
column8: and cultural groups. We ought to be very proud in our country
column9: as most Americans are
column10: that we've made tremendous progress
column11: but we ought to recognize that we have more work to do. Now
column12: the first thing that we are trying to do is to create a million new jobs in the inner cities of this country
column13: with tax credits for employers who hire people who are now unemployed. We are seeking to have vigorous enforcement of the laws that bar discrimination. Now
column14: I want to congratulate Mr. Kemp for being a lonely voice in the Republican party over the years on this question. It is -- it is with some sadness that I refer to the fact that the day after he joined Senator Dole's ticket
column15: he announced that he was changing his position and was hereto
column16: thereafter going to adopt Senator Dole's position to end all affirmative action. That's not good for our country. Bill Clinton and I believe that the United States of America has its brightest days ahead
column17: and we will see them even brighter if we promote diversity and harmony among all our people.

column2: my position on Affirmative Action has been clear ever since I left the professional football career for Congress in 1970. Some people think I quit playing a few years earlier
column3: but I retired in 1970. My life has been dedicated to equality of opportunity and our democracy should provide that
column4: not equality of reward. Uh
column5: Affirmative Action should be predicated upon need
column6: not equality of reward
column7: not equality of outcome. Quotas have always been against the American ideal. We should promote diversity and we should do it the way Bob Dole has been talking about
column8: with a new civil rights agenda
column9: based upon expanding access to credit and capital
column10: job opportunities
column11: educational choice in our inner cities for a young urban mother who can't get the type of an education she wants for her child
column12: and
column13: ultimately
column14: the type of ownership and entrepreneurship from public housing in
column15: D.C. to Nickerson Gardens in Watts
column16: Los Angeles. People need to own. And that's what Abraham Lincoln believed. That when people own something
column17: they have a stake in the American dream. That is Affirmative Action in America.

column2: I do not believe that Abraham Lincoln would have adopted Bob Dole's position to end all affirmative action. There is a specific measure on the ballot in California. It was embodied in legislation
column3: introduced by Senator Dole
column4: to apply to the whole nation. Mr. Kemp campaigned against it
column5: spoke against it
column6: wrote letters against it
column7: went to California to fight against it
column8: and now has endorsed it. I don't think it's a minor matter. I think this is one of the most important challenges that our country has to face in the future

column10: instead of the other way around.
