column1: The problem with this version of Niagara Falls is that Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp would put the economy in a barrel and send it over the falls. [ Laughter ] It is a risky
column2: $550-billion tax scheme that actually raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest working families. Again
column3: Mr. Kemp opposed that and called it unconscionable. Now
column4: it is part of the plan that he is supporting. Not only that
column5: though
column6: it would blow a hole in the deficit
column7: it would raise interest rates. That means higher mortgage payments
column8: particularly those with the variable rate mortgages
column9: higher car payments
column10: he would also lead to much deeper cuts in Medicare
column11: Medicaid
column12: education and the environment. It is extremely risky. And as for these harsh words
column13: I don't take them personally. He said much worse about Bob Dole when he said Bob Dole never met a tax that he didn't hike. He wrote about 450 separate provisions in that code. You better check with him before you eliminate it completely. He may be getting royalties.

column2: a $550-billion tax cut
column3: this is something that Al does not want to mention
column4: has to be viewed against the context of a $50-trillion U.S. economy output of goods and services over the next six years. A $550-billion tax cut in a $50-trillion economy over six years is one-and-a-half percent
column5: and the only hole it would blow is a hole in the plans of this administration to try to tinker with the tax code and defend the indefensible. It would blow up the bureaucracy
column6: but you would expand the economy. That's important for America.

column1: We've passed the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We have fought for new provisions that now make it possible to file over the telephone. We are fighting for tax reforms across-the-board

column3: we have a plan on the table right now to cut taxes on middle income families with several specific provisions. We already cut taxes on 15 million working families in this county
column4: with an average of about $1
column5: 000 in tax relief to those making $25
column6: 000 a year or less. And for the last two years

column14: capital gains eliminated for the sale of a home
column15: a tax break for first-time home buyers and for health care expenses and a $500 child tax credit.

column2: Medicare is too important to senior citizens around this country to play the type of politics that is being played on this issue. It is losing $8 billion as we stand here tonight. By the President's own trustees of Medicare

column10: you cannot balance the budget
column11: Jim
column12: without growing this economy. It's only growing at about two-and-a-half percent. We should double the rate of growth and double the size of American economy. This means more jobs
column13: more wealth
column14: more income and more capital
column15: particularly for our nation's poor and those left behind.

column2: our balanced budget plan extends the Medicare Trust Fund ten years into the future. A commission is fine
column3: but a commission would not do any good if we adopted this risky $550-billion tax scheme. The word ""scary"" has been used. A couple of days ago I went with Governor Lawton Chiles
column4: who was here
column5: to Sarasota to the Friendship Senior Center. I talked with a woman there named Dorothy Wornell and she said
column6: ""You know
column7: we may not be as sophisticated as some of those people in Washington
column8: but we can add and subtract."" Here are the numbers she's adding and subtracting. Bob Dole's plan would have already imposed an extra $268 on the average Medicare receiving couple
column9: and his plan would have doubled deductibles. It would have cost an extra $1
column10: 700 over the lifetime of his plan and eliminated nursing home standards and guarantees of nursing home care for seniors. Bill Clinton prevented it from happening. We will never allow that to happen.

column2: Medicare is too important to senior citizens around this country to play the type of politics that is being played on this issue. It is losing $8 billion as we stand here tonight. By the President's own trustees of Medicare
column3: three members of which serve in his cabinet
column4: it will be losing $23 billion a year by 1998. Something must be done. Bob Dole is -- has suggested a commission
column5: but
column6: clearly
column7: you cannot save Medicare
column8: Social Security
column9: or any program for the social welfare net of American people
column10: under which they should not be allowed to fall
column11: unless we grow this economy at least twice the rate it is growing today. That is the issue
column12: not scaring people in America.

column2: as I said before
column3: he used much harsher language when he talked about Bob Dole. He said that Bob Dole's solution for every single problem was to increase taxes. He said just two years ago that the Bob Dole tax increase of 1982 was the largest tax increase in the history of the world
column4: but let's get to the point. Medicare has been adjusted 23 times since it was created in 1965. Bob Dole
column5: incidentally
column6: just bragged this year that he was one of only 12 people who voted against the creation of Medicare in the first place. I don't think he's -- he didn't believe in it then
column7: and the plan that he promoted last year would have certainly been devastating to Medicare. Again
column8: don't take my word for it. The American Hospital Association said it could have closed 700 hospitals. The Catholic Health Association
column9: the AARP
column10: and many other groups who pay careful attention to Medicare said that the Dole/Gingrich plan on Medicare would have led to deep cuts
column11: possibly set up a two-tiered system
column12: and would have ended the kind of Medicare system that we have. Our plan extends Medicare ten years into the future. We will always protect Medicare within the context of a balanced budget plan.

column2: they have no plan. They have absolutely no plan. The President himself suggested that the reduction in the growth of Medicare over the next five or six years ought to be held to 6 percent under the Republican plan
column3: irrespective of the numbers
column4: it will grow at 7 or even more percent
column5: but that is beside the point. What has to be discussed is how we
column6: as a nation
column7: are going to create the size of an economy
column8: create a national wealth that would at least double this 6 or 7 trillion economy. We would have $6 trillion in 15 years extra wealth for the American people. Another trillion dollars of revenue
column9: with which to save Medicare and Social Security. And you can't do it with a tax code and a regulatory code and people suing each other with frivolous suits
column10: as this administration is allowing to happen. That has to change
column11: and it will under Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

column1: I think Mr. Kemp has unintentionally made a mistake in saying that President Clinton called for reduction of -- to 6 percent or whatever you said. I believe you were referring to the ""Money"" magazine interview
column2: and the publisher of ""Money"" magazine just sent Mr. Kemp a letter two days ago asking him to please stop inaccurately citing ""Money"" magazine. It is not what the President said. It is not the President's position. Let me make clear what his position is. We will save Medicare. We will stop efforts to hurt Medicare
column3: and we'll do it within a balanced budget plan.

column2: but for the record
column3: I would like to release the letter to our friends in the press of the letter I got from ""Money"" magazine
column4: suggesting that Bill Clinton wanted and did lower the cost of living allowance for senior citizens as a way of reducing Social Security.

column4: we really do. Um
column5: this country has yet to deal with the type of inclusionary policies. It is so very important for Americans
column6: white and black
column7: Jew and Christian
column8: immigrant and native-born
column9: to sit down and talk and listen and begin to understand what it's like to come from that different perspective. Our country is as the Kerner Commission Report suggested a number of years ago was being split
column10: but they said between white and black. I think it's being split
column11: Jim
column12: not so much between white and black
column13: although that's still a very serious problem. We really have two economies. Our general economy
column14: our national economy
column15: our mainstream economy is democratic
column16: is based on incentives
column17: a small ""d"" Al
column18: it's capitalism and incentives for working and saving and investing and producing
column19: and families and the things that really lead to progress up that ladder that we call ""The American Dream
column20: but is what is really universal. But unfortunately
column22: and I was glad to hear the Vice President talk a little bit about it
column23: uh there -- they have abandoned the inner cities. There's a socialist economy. There's no private housing. There's mostly public housing. You're told where to go to school
column24: you're told what to buy with food stamps. It is a welfare system that is more like a third-world socialist country than what we would expect from the world's greatest democratic free-enterprise system. That must change
column25: and it will under Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

column1: Remember what I said just a moment ago. If it were not so
column2: he would have told you. The problems between races in America must be addressed. The good news is we're making progress. We've seen 10.5 million new jobs created in the last four years. We've seen the unemployment rate come down dramatically. We've seen the African-American unemployment rate go below double digits for the first time in 25 years and it stayed below for 25 months in a row. We have empowerment zones and enterprise communities
column3: 105 of them in communities all across the United States of America. Let me tell you a story about Joann Crowder in Detroit. She was on welfare for eight years until the empowerment zone was created there. She just got a job in the new business that -- that launched its enterprise right in that empowerment zone. We want to do that for millions more all across the country.

column2: with all due respect
column3: Jim
column4: there are nine empowerment zones
column5: a few little tinkering with tax credits around the country for inner cities. Los Angeles
column6: after the riots
column7: did not even get an empowerment zone
column8: believe it or not. That is just unconscionable in America to have left Watts
column9: South Central and East L.A. out. Earl Graves of ""Black Enterprise"" magazine said the single greatest deterrent to black advancement is the lack of access to capital
column10: the credit and ownership. That will change. We will green-line every city in the United States where there is unemployment and welfare and we will eliminate the Capital Gains Tax
column11: eliminate the tax on a welfare mother that takes a job. That is the answer. Give ownership and entrepreneurship to low income people based on need
column12: not the color of their skin.

column1: Before I answer that specific question
column2: let me say that we did put an empowerment zone in South Central
column3: Los Angeles. It is in the form of the largest community development financial institution ever created in the United States or in any other country and it is creating jobs in South Central
column4: Los Angeles right now. The Congress passed uh an enterprise zone after the Los Angeles riots five years ago. It was vetoed by the prior administration. Now
column5: to your question. We have a specific plan to create 1 million new jobs in the inner cities of America with tax credits for employers who hire people coming off welfare
column6: 'cause we've passed welfare reform now
column7: we promised to end welfare as we know it. And we are implementing this new legislation. We have moved 1.9 million people off of the welfare rolls and into good jobs in the last four years. Our new plan is to have 1 million more jobs in the inner cities
column8: but that's not all. We are also implementing the plan to put 100
column9: 000 community police officers in our cities. We've already got 20
column10: 000 out there. We're ahead of our six-year schedule. As a matter of fact
column11: there're 8 here in St. Petersburg
column12: already on the beat
column13: you may run into one of them leaving this auditorium tonight. St. Petersburg is safer because of this urban agenda that we're following. We want the focus to be on millions more jobs
column14: and we're very optimistic that it's gonna happen.

column2: we've had four years and there's no enterprise zone. There are empowerment zones
column3: but you have to do what Bill Clinton and Al Gore want you to do. You get a $5
column4: 000 tax credit if you hire somebody that's unemployed
column5: but you've already got to have an existing business. The answer is to say
column6: once again
column7: green-line any area in America that has been red-lined for lack of mortgage money
column8: lack of credit and capital. Just say that area qualifies for no Capital Gains Tax
column9: zero
column10: nada. That's what Eleanor Holmes Norton wants to do in the District of Columbia and this administration said to D.C.
column11: Drop dead. Drop dead. We don't want to change the legislation that would lower the tax rate in D.C.
column12: allow welfare mothers to take a job without any tax on the first 90 percent of her income and no Capital Gain Tax that should be done in every urban area of America that would make capital flow back
column13: and you can't have capitalism
column14: Al
column15: without capital. You may want to give a tax credit
column16: but it won't work.

column2: we have 105 empowerment zones and enterprise communities all across the United States of America
column3: and with all due respect
column4: that's 105 more than were there when we came into the White House. We have been implementing them in a determined way. They are making a difference. You know
column5: that empowerment zone that I mentioned in Detroit is creating jobs not only for Joann Crowder
column6: who feels proud that she's off of welfare now
column7: and we're proud of her. It's creating jobs for hundreds of others
column8: and similar initiatives are working in the other empowerment zones.

column1: The single greatest problem in our opinion
column2: domestic -- in the domestic economy
column3: is that this tax code
column4: 83 years old
column5: a relic of the Cold War and Hot War
column6: inflation and depression
column7: seven-and-a-half million words long
column8: overtaxes capital
column9: overtaxes working men and women and families. Clearly
column10: the Gordian knot needs to be broken in one fell swoop. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp
column11: as soon as we get through this first step of cutting tax rates across the board
column12: are going to repeal the whole code while Bill Clinton and my friend
column13: Al Gore
column14: defend the status quo. We're going to repeal the seven-and-a-half million words of the U.S.tax code
column15: make it tax income once
column16: not twice
column17: three
column18: four
column19: and if you die
column20: it confiscates your estate. We must have a tax code going into the 21st Century that does not protect the establishment and this tax code does. And by cutting and eliminating the Capital Gains
column21: by cutting and eliminating the Estate Tax
column22: by bringing the top tax rate down to something reasonable
column23: like -- here he goes again -- I think in peacetime
column24: it shouldn't be higher
column25: Bob
column26: and I don't think it should be higher than 25 percent
column27: phased in. But capital would flow out into the economy. We have people getting access to capital. Small businessmen and women
column28: African-American
column30: Latino Americans
column31: female Americans would be able to start their businesses. Dana Crist of Lancaster said the day the tax bill is passed in Congress
column32: she will open a new factory with 40 or 50 or 60 employees in Lancaster
column33: Pennsylvania. He'll call that trickle down. I'll call it Niagara Falls.

column1: The problem with this version of Niagara Falls is that Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp would put the economy in a barrel and send it over the falls. [ Laughter ] It is a risky
column2: $550-billion tax scheme that actually raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest working families. Again
column3: Mr. Kemp opposed that and called it unconscionable. Now
column4: it is part of the plan that he is supporting. Not only that
column5: though
column6: it would blow a hole in the deficit
column7: it would raise interest rates. That means higher mortgage payments
column8: particularly those with the variable rate mortgages
column9: higher car payments
column10: he would also lead to much deeper cuts in Medicare
column11: Medicaid
column12: education and the environment. It is extremely risky. And as for these harsh words
column13: I don't take them personally. He said much worse about Bob Dole when he said Bob Dole never met a tax that he didn't hike. He wrote about 450 separate provisions in that code. You better check with him before you eliminate it completely. He may be getting royalties.

column2: a $550-billion tax cut
column3: this is something that Al does not want to mention
column4: has to be viewed against the context of a $50-trillion U.S. economy output of goods and services over the next six years. A $550-billion tax cut in a $50-trillion economy over six years is one-and-a-half percent
column5: and the only hole it would blow is a hole in the plans of this administration to try to tinker with the tax code and defend the indefensible. It would blow up the bureaucracy
column6: but you would expand the economy. That's important for America.

column1: We've passed the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We have fought for new provisions that now make it possible to file over the telephone. We are fighting for tax reforms across-the-board
column2: and most importantly
column3: we have a plan on the table right now to cut taxes on middle income families with several specific provisions. We already cut taxes on 15 million working families in this county
column4: with an average of about $1
column5: 000 in tax relief to those making $25
column6: 000 a year or less. And for the last two years
column7: we have had middle-income tax cuts on the table in the Congress and they would not -- they weren't accepted by Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich
column8: because they said they would not pass them without cutting deeply into Medicare
column9: Medicaid
column10: education and the environment. We are determined to move forward during these next four years
column11: with the tax cuts that president Bill Clinton has proposed. Here they are again: A $1500 tax credit for tuition
column13: 000 tax deduction so that no family pays taxes on the money for college tuition
column14: capital gains eliminated for the sale of a home
column15: a tax break for first-time home buyers and for health care expenses and a $500 child tax credit.

column1: You only get a tax cut in the Clinton administration if you do exactly what Al Gore and Bill Clinton want you to do. That's not America. When John F. Kennedy cut tax rates
column2: the economy grew
column3: unemployment went down and we balanced the budget
column4: and revenues went up. Indeed
column5: the Secretary of Treasury under John F. Kennedy and the Deputy Secretary of Treasury under John F. Kennedy endorsed Bob Dole's plan to cut rates
column6: cut the Capital Gains Tax
column7: balance the budget
column8: provide a $500 tax credit
column9: and
column10: clearly
column11: the plan should be to lift the economy
column12: to get more revenues. Medicare will be saved because it will be put into a commission where both Bill Clinton and Bob Dole recognize it has to be studied by the same people that would study -- or did study
column13: I should say
column14: the Social Security System and saved it in 1983 and '84. Look
column15: we can bring down government -- the growth of government spending
column16: but we have to grow the economy. And in Bob Dole and Jack Kemp's opinion
column17: we should aim at doubling the size of the American economy in the next 15 years. Under their policies
column18: it will take 30 to 40 years. That's not acceptable.

column1: The chairman of their national campaign steering committee
column2: Senator D'Amato
column3: said that Bob Dole would have to cut into Medicare in order to pay for this proposal
column4: but that he would wait until after the election to do it. The proposal to cut Medicare that Senator Dole pushed before
column5: and shut down the government to try to enact
column6: would have already raised by $268
column7: the fees paid by the average couple now on Medicare. He tried to double the deductibles and give people less in return. We have a balanced budget plan that protects Medicare and gives tax cuts.

column2: Jim
column3: let me just say it is disgraceful
column4: the campaign being waged to scare the American senior citizens
column5: in this state and my home state of
column6: well
column7: New York and California
column8: about Medicare.

column2: isn't there?
Maryland now. The amount of money being spent to try to mislead the American people is demagoguery
column3: and only in the Clinton White House and in Al Gore's mind could an increase in spending per capita on a senior citizen from $4800 in 1996 to $7200 over the next five years be considered a cut. Does anybody think that Bob Dole
column4: who almost gave his life for his country
column5: who has served in the Senate
column6: who helped save Social Security
column7: crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in Northern Italy in 1945 to save a wounded radioman? Does anybody think in this country that he could possibly want to move our country ahead and leave anybody behind? Of course
column8: we can balance the budget. Of course
column9: we have to hold down the growth in entitlement spending. But clearly
column10: you cannot balance the budget
column11: Jim
column12: without growing this economy. It's only growing at about two-and-a-half percent. We should double the rate of growth and double the size of American economy. This means more jobs
column13: more wealth
column14: more income and more capital
column15: particularly for our nation's poor and those left behind.

column2: our balanced budget plan extends the Medicare Trust Fund ten years into the future. A commission is fine
column3: but a commission would not do any good if we adopted this risky $550-billion tax scheme. The word ""scary"" has been used. A couple of days ago I went with Governor Lawton Chiles
column4: who was here
column5: to Sarasota to the Friendship Senior Center. I talked with a woman there named Dorothy Wornell and she said
column6: ""You know
column7: we may not be as sophisticated as some of those people in Washington
column8: but we can add and subtract."" Here are the numbers she's adding and subtracting. Bob Dole's plan would have already imposed an extra $268 on the average Medicare receiving couple
column9: and his plan would have doubled deductibles. It would have cost an extra $1
column10: 700 over the lifetime of his plan and eliminated nursing home standards and guarantees of nursing home care for seniors. Bill Clinton prevented it from happening. We will never allow that to happen.

column2: Medicare is too important to senior citizens around this country to play the type of politics that is being played on this issue. It is losing $8 billion as we stand here tonight. By the President's own trustees of Medicare
column3: three members of which serve in his cabinet
column4: it will be losing $23 billion a year by 1998. Something must be done. Bob Dole is -- has suggested a commission
column5: but
column6: clearly
column7: you cannot save Medicare
column8: Social Security
column9: or any program for the social welfare net of American people
column10: under which they should not be allowed to fall
column11: unless we grow this economy at least twice the rate it is growing today. That is the issue
column12: not scaring people in America.

column2: as I said before
column3: he used much harsher language when he talked about Bob Dole. He said that Bob Dole's solution for every single problem was to increase taxes. He said just two years ago that the Bob Dole tax increase of 1982 was the largest tax increase in the history of the world
column4: but let's get to the point. Medicare has been adjusted 23 times since it was created in 1965. Bob Dole
column5: incidentally
column6: just bragged this year that he was one of only 12 people who voted against the creation of Medicare in the first place. I don't think he's -- he didn't believe in it then
column7: and the plan that he promoted last year would have certainly been devastating to Medicare. Again
column8: don't take my word for it. The American Hospital Association said it could have closed 700 hospitals. The Catholic Health Association
column9: the AARP
column10: and many other groups who pay careful attention to Medicare said that the Dole/Gingrich plan on Medicare would have led to deep cuts
column11: possibly set up a two-tiered system
column12: and would have ended the kind of Medicare system that we have. Our plan extends Medicare ten years into the future. We will always protect Medicare within the context of a balanced budget plan.

column2: they have no plan. They have absolutely no plan. The President himself suggested that the reduction in the growth of Medicare over the next five or six years ought to be held to 6 percent under the Republican plan
column3: irrespective of the numbers
column4: it will grow at 7 or even more percent
column5: but that is beside the point. What has to be discussed is how we
column6: as a nation
column7: are going to create the size of an economy
column8: create a national wealth that would at least double this 6 or 7 trillion economy. We would have $6 trillion in 15 years extra wealth for the American people. Another trillion dollars of revenue
column9: with which to save Medicare and Social Security. And you can't do it with a tax code and a regulatory code and people suing each other with frivolous suits
column10: as this administration is allowing to happen. That has to change
column11: and it will under Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

column1: I think Mr. Kemp has unintentionally made a mistake in saying that President Clinton called for reduction of -- to 6 percent or whatever you said. I believe you were referring to the ""Money"" magazine interview
column2: and the publisher of ""Money"" magazine just sent Mr. Kemp a letter two days ago asking him to please stop inaccurately citing ""Money"" magazine. It is not what the President said. It is not the President's position. Let me make clear what his position is. We will save Medicare. We will stop efforts to hurt Medicare
column3: and we'll do it within a balanced budget plan.

column2: but for the record

column7: Jew and Christian
column8: immigrant and native-born
column9: to sit down and talk and listen and begin to understand what it's like to come from that different perspective. Our country is as the Kerner Commission Report suggested a number of years ago was being split
column10: but they said between white and black. I think it's being split
column11: Jim
column12: not so much between white and black
column13: although that's still a very serious problem. We really have two economies. Our general economy
column14: our national economy
column15: our mainstream economy is democratic
column16: is based on incentives
column17: a small ""d"" Al
column18: it's capitalism and incentives for working and saving and investing and producing
column19: and families and the things that really lead to progress up that ladder that we call ""The American Dream
column20: but is what is really universal. But unfortunately
column22: and I was glad to hear the Vice President talk a little bit about it
column23: uh there -- they have abandoned the inner cities. There's a socialist economy. There's no private housing. There's mostly public housing. You're told where to go to school
column24: you're told what to buy with food stamps. It is a welfare system that is more like a third-world socialist country than what we would expect from the world's greatest democratic free-enterprise system. That must change
column25: and it will under Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

column1: Remember what I said just a moment ago. If it were not so
column2: he would have told you. The problems between races in America must be addressed. The good news is we're making progress. We've seen 10.5 million new jobs created in the last four years. We've seen the unemployment rate come down dramatically. We've seen the African-American unemployment rate go below double digits for the first time in 25 years and it stayed below for 25 months in a row. We have empowerment zones and enterprise communities
column3: 105 of them in communities all across the United States of America. Let me tell you a story about Joann Crowder in Detroit. She was on welfare for eight years until the empowerment zone was created there. She just got a job in the new business that -- that launched its enterprise right in that empowerment zone. We want to do that for millions more all across the country.

column2: with all due respect
column3: Jim
column4: there are nine empowerment zones
column5: a few little tinkering with tax credits around the country for inner cities. Los Angeles
column6: after the riots
column7: did not even get an empowerment zone
column8: believe it or not. That is just unconscionable in America to have left Watts
column9: South Central and East L.A. out. Earl Graves of ""Black Enterprise"" magazine said the single greatest deterrent to black advancement is the lack of access to capital
column10: the credit and ownership. That will change. We will green-line every city in the United States where there is unemployment and welfare and we will eliminate the Capital Gains Tax
column11: eliminate the tax on a welfare mother that takes a job. That is the answer. Give ownership and entrepreneurship to low income people based on need
column12: not the color of their skin.

column1: Before I answer that specific question
column2: let me say that we did put an empowerment zone in South Central
column3: Los Angeles. It is in the form of the largest community development financial institution ever created in the United States or in any other country and it is creating jobs in South Central
column4: Los Angeles right now. The Congress passed uh an enterprise zone after the Los Angeles riots five years ago. It was vetoed by the prior administration. Now
column5: to your question. We have a specific plan to create 1 million new jobs in the inner cities of America with tax credits for employers who hire people coming off welfare
column6: 'cause we've passed welfare reform now
column7: we promised to end welfare as we know it. And we are implementing this new legislation. We have moved 1.9 million people off of the welfare rolls and into good jobs in the last four years. Our new plan is to have 1 million more jobs in the inner cities
column8: but that's not all. We are also implementing the plan to put 100
column9: 000 community police officers in our cities. We've already got 20
column10: 000 out there. We're ahead of our six-year schedule. As a matter of fact
column11: there're 8 here in St. Petersburg
column12: already on the beat
column13: you may run into one of them leaving this auditorium tonight. St. Petersburg is safer because of this urban agenda that we're following. We want the focus to be on millions more jobs
column14: and we're very optimistic that it's gonna happen.

column2: we've had four years and there's no enterprise zone. There are empowerment zones
column3: but you have to do what Bill Clinton and Al Gore want you to do. You get a $5
column4: 000 tax credit if you hire somebody that's unemployed
column5: but you've already got to have an existing business. The answer is to say
column6: once again
column7: green-line any area in America that has been red-lined for lack of mortgage money
column8: lack of credit and capital. Just say that area qualifies for no Capital Gains Tax
column9: zero
column10: nada. That's what Eleanor Holmes Norton wants to do in the District of Columbia and this administration said to D.C.
column11: Drop dead. Drop dead. We don't want to change the legislation that would lower the tax rate in D.C.
column12: allow welfare mothers to take a job without any tax on the first 90 percent of her income and no Capital Gain Tax that should be done in every urban area of America that would make capital flow back
column13: and you can't have capitalism
column14: Al
column15: without capital. You may want to give a tax credit
column16: but it won't work.

column2: we have 105 empowerment zones and enterprise communities all across the United States of America
column3: and with all due respect
column4: that's 105 more than were there when we came into the White House. We have been implementing them in a determined way. They are making a difference. You know
column5: that empowerment zone that I mentioned in Detroit is creating jobs not only for Joann Crowder
column6: who feels proud that she's off of welfare now
column7: and we're proud of her. It's creating jobs for hundreds of others
column8: and similar initiatives are working in the other empowerment zones.

column1: The single greatest problem in our opinion
column2: domestic -- in the domestic economy
column3: is that this tax code
column4: 83 years old
column5: a relic of the Cold War and Hot War
column6: inflation and depression
column7: seven-and-a-half million words long
column8: overtaxes capital
column9: overtaxes working men and women and families. Clearly
column10: the Gordian knot needs to be broken in one fell swoop. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp
column11: as soon as we get through this first step of cutting tax rates across the board
column12: are going to repeal the whole code while Bill Clinton and my friend
column13: Al Gore
column14: defend the status quo. We're going to repeal the seven-and-a-half million words of the U.S.tax code
column15: make it tax income once
column16: not twice
column17: three
column18: four
column19: and if you die
column20: it confiscates your estate. We must have a tax code going into the 21st Century that does not protect the establishment and this tax code does. And by cutting and eliminating the Capital Gains
column21: by cutting and eliminating the Estate Tax
column22: by bringing the top tax rate down to something reasonable
column23: like -- here he goes again -- I think in peacetime
column24: it shouldn't be higher
column25: Bob
column26: and I don't think it should be higher than 25 percent
column27: phased in. But capital would flow out into the economy. We have people getting access to capital. Small businessmen and women
column28: African-American
column30: Latino Americans
column31: female Americans would be able to start their businesses. Dana Crist of Lancaster said the day the tax bill is passed in Congress
column32: she will open a new factory with 40 or 50 or 60 employees in Lancaster
column33: Pennsylvania. He'll call that trickle down. I'll call it Niagara Falls.

column1: The problem with this version of Niagara Falls is that Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp would put the economy in a barrel and send it over the falls. [ Laughter ] It is a risky
column2: $550-billion tax scheme that actually raises taxes on 9 million of the hardest working families. Again
column3: Mr. Kemp opposed that and called it unconscionable. Now
column4: it is part of the plan that he is supporting. Not only that
column5: though
column6: it would blow a hole in the deficit
column7: it would raise interest rates. That means higher mortgage payments
column8: particularly those with the variable rate mortgages
column9: higher car payments
column10: he would also lead to much deeper cuts in Medicare
column11: Medicaid
column12: education and the environment. It is extremely risky. And as for these harsh words
column13: I don't take them personally. He said much worse about Bob Dole when he said Bob Dole never met a tax that he didn't hike. He wrote about 450 separate provisions in that code. You better check with him before you eliminate it completely. He may be getting royalties.

column2: a $550-billion tax cut
column3: this is something that Al does not want to mention
column4: has to be viewed against the context of a $50-trillion U.S. economy output of goods and services over the next six years. A $550-billion tax cut in a $50-trillion economy over six years is one-and-a-half percent
column5: and the only hole it would blow is a hole in the plans of this administration to try to tinker with the tax code and defend the indefensible. It would blow up the bureaucracy
column6: but you would expand the economy. That's important for America.

column1: We've passed the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We have fought for new provisions that now make it possible to file over the telephone. We are fighting for tax reforms across-the-board
column2: and most importantly
column3: we have a plan on the table right now to cut taxes on middle income families with several specific provisions. We already cut taxes on 15 million working families in this county
column4: with an average of about $1
column5: 000 in tax relief to those making $25
column6: 000 a year or less. And for the last two years
column7: we have had middle-income tax cuts on the table in the Congress and they would not -- they weren't accepted by Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich
column8: because they said they would not pass them without cutting deeply into Medicare
column9: Medicaid
column10: education and the environment. We are determined to move forward during these next four years
column11: with the tax cuts that president Bill Clinton has proposed. Here they are again: A $1500 tax credit for tuition
column13: 000 tax deduction so that no family pays taxes on the money for college tuition
column14: capital gains eliminated for the sale of a home
column15: a tax break for first-time home buyers and for health care expenses and a $500 child tax credit.

column1: You only get a tax cut in the Clinton administration if you do exactly what Al Gore and Bill Clinton want you to do. That's not America. When John F. Kennedy cut tax rates
column2: the economy grew
column3: unemployment went down and we balanced the budget
column4: and revenues went up. Indeed
column5: the Secretary of Treasury under John F. Kennedy and the Deputy Secretary of Treasury under John F. Kennedy endorsed Bob Dole's plan to cut rates
column6: cut the Capital Gains Tax
column7: balance the budget
column8: provide a $500 tax credit
column9: and
column10: clearly
column11: the plan should be to lift the economy
column12: to get more revenues. Medicare will be saved because it will be put into a commission where both Bill Clinton and Bob Dole recognize it has to be studied by the same people that would study -- or did study
column13: I should say
column14: the Social Security System and saved it in 1983 and '84. Look
column15: we can bring down government -- the growth of government spending
column16: but we have to grow the economy. And in Bob Dole and Jack Kemp's opinion
column17: we should aim at doubling the size of the American economy in the next 15 years. Under their policies
column18: it will take 30 to 40 years. That's not acceptable.

column1: The chairman of their national campaign steering committee
column2: Senator D'Amato
column3: said that Bob Dole would have to cut into Medicare in order to pay for this proposal
column4: but that he would wait until after the election to do it. The proposal to cut Medicare that Senator Dole pushed before
column5: and shut down the government to try to enact
column6: would have already raised by $268
column7: the fees paid by the average couple now on Medicare. He tried to double the deductibles and give people less in return. We have a balanced budget plan that protects Medicare and gives tax cuts.

column2: Jim
column3: let me just say it is disgraceful
column4: the campaign being waged to scare the American senior citizens
column5: in this state and my home state of
column6: well
column7: New York and California
column8: about Medicare.

column2: isn't there?
Maryland now. The amount of money being spent to try to mislead the American people is demagoguery
column3: and only in the Clinton White House and in Al Gore's mind could an increase in spending per capita on a senior citizen from $4800 in 1996 to $7200 over the next five years be considered a cut. Does anybody think that Bob Dole
column4: who almost gave his life for his country
column5: who has served in the Senate
column6: who helped save Social Security
column7: crawled out of a fox hole on Riva Ridge in Northern Italy in 1945 to save a wounded radioman? Does anybody think in this country that he could possibly want to move our country ahead and leave anybody behind? Of course
column8: we can balance the budget. Of course
column9: we have to hold down the growth in entitlement spending. But clearly
column10: you cannot balance the budget
column11: Jim
column12: without growing this economy. It's only growing at about two-and-a-half percent. We should double the rate of growth and double the size of American economy. This means more jobs
column13: more wealth
column14: more income and more capital
column15: particularly for our nation's poor and those left behind.

column2: our balanced budget plan extends the Medicare Trust Fund ten years into the future. A commission is fine
column3: but a commission would not do any good if we adopted this risky $550-billion tax scheme. The word ""scary"" has been used. A couple of days ago I went with Governor Lawton Chiles
column4: who was here
column5: to Sarasota to the Friendship Senior Center. I talked with a woman there named Dorothy Wornell and she said
column6: ""You know
column7: we may not be as sophisticated as some of those people in Washington
column8: but we can add and subtract."" Here are the numbers she's adding and subtracting. Bob Dole's plan would have already imposed an extra $268 on the average Medicare receiving couple
column9: and his plan would have doubled deductibles. It would have cost an extra $1
column10: 700 over the lifetime of his plan and eliminated nursing home standards and guarantees of nursing home care for seniors. Bill Clinton prevented it from happening. We will never allow that to happen.

column2: Medicare is too important to senior citizens around this country to play the type of politics that is being played on this issue. It is losing $8 billion as we stand here tonight. By the President's own trustees of Medicare
column3: three members of which serve in his cabinet
column4: it will be losing $23 billion a year by 1998. Something must be done. Bob Dole is -- has suggested a commission
column5: but
column6: clearly
column7: you cannot save Medicare
column8: Social Security
column9: or any program for the social welfare net of American people
column10: under which they should not be allowed to fall
column11: unless we grow this economy at least twice the rate it is growing today. That is the issue
column12: not scaring people in America.

column2: as I said before
column3: he used much harsher language when he talked about Bob Dole. He said that Bob Dole's solution for every single problem was to increase taxes. He said just two years ago that the Bob Dole tax increase of 1982 was the largest tax increase in the history of the world
column4: but let's get to the point. Medicare has been adjusted 23 times since it was created in 1965. Bob Dole
column5: incidentally
column6: just bragged this year that he was one of only 12 people who voted against the creation of Medicare in the first place. I don't think he's -- he didn't believe in it then
column7: and the plan that he promoted last year would have certainly been devastating to Medicare. Again
column8: don't take my word for it. The American Hospital Association said it could have closed 700 hospitals. The Catholic Health Association
column9: the AARP
column10: and many other groups who pay careful attention to Medicare said that the Dole/Gingrich plan on Medicare would have led to deep cuts
column11: possibly set up a two-tiered system
column12: and would have ended the kind of Medicare system that we have. Our plan extends Medicare ten years into the future. We will always protect Medicare within the context of a balanced budget plan.

column2: they have no plan. They have absolutely no plan. The President himself suggested that the reduction in the growth of Medicare over the next five or six years ought to be held to 6 percent under the Republican plan
column3: irrespective of the numbers
column4: it will grow at 7 or even more percent
column5: but that is beside the point. What has to be discussed is how we
column6: as a nation
column7: are going to create the size of an economy
column8: create a national wealth that would at least double this 6 or 7 trillion economy. We would have $6 trillion in 15 years extra wealth for the American people. Another trillion dollars of revenue
column9: with which to save Medicare and Social Security. And you can't do it with a tax code and a regulatory code and people suing each other with frivolous suits
column10: as this administration is allowing to happen. That has to change
column11: and it will under Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.

column1: I think Mr. Kemp has unintentionally made a mistake in saying that President Clinton called for reduction of -- to 6 percent or whatever you said. I believe you were referring to the ""Money"" magazine interview
column2: and the publisher of ""Money"" magazine just sent Mr. Kemp a letter two days ago asking him to please stop inaccurately citing ""Money"" magazine. It is not what the President said. It is not the President's position. Let me make clear what his position is. We will save Medicare. We will stop efforts to hurt Medicare
column3: and we'll do it within a balanced budget plan.

column2: but for the record
column3: I would like to release the letter to our friends in the press of the letter I got from ""Money"" magazine
column4: suggesting that Bill Clinton wanted and did lower the cost of living allowance for senior citizens as a way of reducing Social Security.

column1: Folks, they have no plan. They have absolutely no plan. column17: as ugly as that might be -- and I know it's a tragedy to many people both on the pro-choice and pro-life position -- we have a President who vetoed a congressional ban on the ugly and gruesome practice of snatching life away from a child just moments before he or she enters the world. That is unacceptable.

column1: President Clinton has made it clear that he will sign legislation outlawing procedures such as this if there is a -- an exception to protect the health of the mother where serious health consequences
column2: such as the inability to have any further children
column3: are involved and her doctor advises her so. What is really at stake here is whether or not women will have the right to choose. The platform on which Mr. Kemp and Senator Dole are running pledges a constitutional amendment to take away a woman's right to choose and to have the government come in and order that woman to do what the government says
column4: no matter what the circumstances. Mr. Kemp has voted 47 out of 47 times to have such an amendment and to restrict this completely

column1: There is no consensus. A constitutional amendment would not pass. We must use persuasion
column2: not intimidation. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp will try to remind the American people of what a tremendous asset our children are and why there should be protection for innocent human life
column3: including that of the unborn. But to think that this administration vetoed the one chance they had to ban that practice without working with people in the Congress who would have loved to have had the opportunity to stop that gruesome practice is just unacceptable to the American people. column3: 4)	" I will answer the question
column4: but for the record
column5: I would like to release the letter to our friends in the press of the letter I got from ""Money"" magazine
column6: suggesting that Bill Clinton wanted and did lower the cost of living allowance for senior citizens as a way of reducing Social Security. Putting that aside
column7: the -- we recognize there's no consensus in America. This country is split between those who call themselves pro-choice
column8: and I'm sure
column9: very sincerely
column10: and those of us who call ourselves pro-life
column11: this is a very emotional issue. I'm sure it is for a woman. It certainly is for those of us like my wife and myself who have three adopted grandchildren. We thank God every night of our life that a young woman was given a choice
column12: was given the opportunity to choose life. This country should not be torn asunder over this debate
column13: it has to be carried out with civility and respect
column14: and Bob and I believe it can be. But we should recognize that every human life is precious and there should be all of the protection that we can give for an unborn human being. And to think that in this country
column15: for every three births
column16: there is one abortion. But even worse than that
column17: as ugly as that might be -- and I know it's a tragedy to many people both on the pro-choice and pro-life position -- we have a President who vetoed a congressional ban on the ugly and gruesome practice of snatching life away from a child just moments before he or she enters the world. That is unacceptable.

column1: President Clinton has made it clear that he will sign legislation outlawing procedures such as this if there is a -- an exception to protect the health of the mother where serious health consequences
column2: such as the inability to have any further children
column3: are involved and her doctor advises her so. What is really at stake here is whether or not women will have the right to choose. The platform on which Mr. Kemp and Senator Dole are running pledges a constitutional amendment to take away a woman's right to choose and to have the government come in and order that woman to do what the government says
column4: no matter what the circumstances. Mr. Kemp has voted 47 out of 47 times to have such an amendment and to restrict this completely
column5: no matter what the circumstances
column6: even where rape and incest is involved. We will never allow a woman's right to choose to be taken away.

column1: There is no consensus. A constitutional amendment would not pass. We must use persuasion
column2: not intimidation. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp will try to remind the American people of what a tremendous asset our children are and why there should be protection for innocent human life
column3: including that of the unborn. But to think that this administration vetoed the one chance they had to ban that practice without working with people in the Congress who would have loved to have had the opportunity to stop that gruesome practice is just unacceptable to the American people. And Bob Dole would never have vetoed that ban on partial-birth abortions in the third trimester of a woman's pregnancy.

That is unacceptable. column3: 5)	" The fighting has stopped in Bosnia. President Bill Clinton showed tremendous courage
column4: vision
column5: wisdom
column6: and leadership in having our country take the lead in rallying our allies
column7: bringing the warring factions together in Dayton
column8: Ohio
column9: and hammering out a peace agreement that has ended the war in Bosnia. We hope that it will stay over with. Elections having just been held. There is great progress towards peace and reconciliation in Bosnia. We ought to be very proud of our soldiers who have played such a critical role in bringing about this peace in Bosnia. It's not the only case where Bill Clinton has provided such leadership. We have restored democracy to Haiti
column10: with scarcely a shot being fired. We have seen movement towards reconciliation in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East. The Bible says there will always be wars and rumors of wars. As the President said the other night
column11: there will always be troubles in this ol' world
column12: but the United States of America can be counted on to provide the vision that the world looks for from the United States of America. Bill Clinton
column13: as President
column14: has provided that kind of leadership. We are more secure and stronger today because of Bill Clinton's handling of foreign policy.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous
column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength
column7: but of weakness. What's worse
column8: they declared victory. They've declared victory in every deployment. We've had more deployments in four years than any previous four years I can think of

column10: and I believed it for my whole career
column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago
column3: we used to hear this phrase in American politics
column4: the ""Blame America First"" crowd. I never liked that phrase
column5: but if it was going to be applied today

column7: and they survived. They're stronger. They're coming back. They paid us back
column8: and we got a dividend in the process.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia

column3: 5)	" The fighting has stopped in Bosnia. President Bill Clinton showed tremendous courage
column4: vision
column5: wisdom
column6: and leadership in having our country take the lead in rallying our allies
column7: bringing the warring factions together in Dayton
column8: Ohio
column9: and hammering out a peace agreement that has ended the war in Bosnia. We hope that it will stay over with. Elections having just been held. There is great progress towards peace and reconciliation in Bosnia. We ought to be very proud of our soldiers who have played such a critical role in bringing about this peace in Bosnia. It's not the only case where Bill Clinton has provided such leadership. We have restored democracy to Haiti
column10: with scarcely a shot being fired. We have seen movement towards reconciliation in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East. The Bible says there will always be wars and rumors of wars. As the President said the other night
column11: there will always be troubles in this ol' world
column12: but the United States of America can be counted on to provide the vision that the world looks for from the United States of America. Bill Clinton
column13: as President
column14: has provided that kind of leadership. We are more secure and stronger today because of Bill Clinton's handling of foreign policy.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous
column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength
column7: but of weakness. What's worse
column8: they declared victory. They've declared victory in every deployment. We've had more deployments in four years than any previous four years I can think of
column9: and I'm 61 years of age. It's unbelievable that ambiguity can be called foreign policy. Let me say what a friend told me
column10: and I believed it for my whole career
column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column3: consult with our allies before we bombed Saddam Hussein

column5: uh it was maybe the right thing to do

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column4: then we have to bail them out. We should have a foreign policy that's predicated upon trade

column6: by giving people opportunities to trade freely with us
column7: and making sure that everybody recognizes a rule of the Golden Rule
column8: ""To do unto others to have them do unto you."" Diplomacy first

column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength

column9: and I'm 61 years of age. It's unbelievable that ambiguity can be called foreign policy. Let me say what a friend told me
column10: and I believed it for my whole career
column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration

column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous

I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago
column3: we used to hear this phrase in American politics

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous
column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength
column7: but of weakness. What's worse
column8: they declared victory. They've declared victory in every deployment. We've had more deployments in four years than any previous four years I can think of

column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column7: and making sure that everybody recognizes a rule of the Golden Rule

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago
column3: we used to hear this phrase in American politics
column4: the ""Blame America First"" crowd. I never liked that phrase
column5: but if it was going to be applied today
column6: it would have to be applied to this statement. The United States of America shouldn't be blamed for the management of Mexico's monetary policy. We helped our neighbor in an hour of need
column7: and they survived. They're stronger. They're coming back. They paid us back
column8: and we got a dividend in the process.

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago

column4: vision
column5: wisdom
column6: and leadership in having our country take the lead in rallying our allies

column8: Ohio

There is great progress towards peace and reconciliation in Bosnia. We ought to be very proud of our soldiers who have played such a critical role in bringing about this peace in Bosnia. It's not the only case where Bill Clinton has provided such leadership. We have restored democracy to Haiti
column10: with scarcely a shot being fired. We have seen movement towards reconciliation in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East. The Bible says there will always be wars and rumors of wars. As the President said the other night
column11: there will always be troubles in this ol' world
column12: but the United States of America can be counted on to provide the vision that the world looks for from the United States of America. Bill Clinton
column13: as President
column14: has provided that kind of leadership. We are more secure and stronger today because of Bill Clinton's handling of foreign policy.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous
column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength
column7: but of weakness. What's worse
column8: they declared victory. They've declared victory in every deployment. We've had more deployments in four years than any previous four years I can think of
column9: and I'm 61 years of age. It's unbelievable that ambiguity can be called foreign policy. Let me say what a friend told me
column10: and I believed it for my whole career
column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago

column3: 5)	" The fighting has stopped in Bosnia. President Bill Clinton showed tremendous courage
column4: vision
column5: wisdom
column6: and leadership in having our country take the lead in rallying our allies
column7: bringing the warring factions together in Dayton
column8: Ohio
column9: and hammering out a peace agreement that has ended the war in Bosnia. We hope that it will stay over with. Elections having just been held. There is great progress towards peace and reconciliation in Bosnia. We ought to be very proud of our soldiers who have played such a critical role in bringing about this peace in Bosnia. It's not the only case where Bill Clinton has provided such leadership. We have restored democracy to Haiti
column10: with scarcely a shot being fired. We have seen movement towards reconciliation in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East. The Bible says there will always be wars and rumors of wars. As the President said the other night
column11: there will always be troubles in this ol' world
column12: but the United States of America can be counted on to provide the vision that the world looks for from the United States of America. Bill Clinton
column13: as President
column14: has provided that kind of leadership. We are more secure and stronger today because of Bill Clinton's handling of foreign policy.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration

column6: not of strength

I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. column2: '09Oct'
column3: 5)	" The fighting has stopped in Bosnia. President Bill Clinton showed tremendous courage
column4: vision
column5: wisdom
column6: and leadership in having our country take the lead in rallying our allies
column7: bringing the warring factions together in Dayton
column8: Ohio
column9: and hammering out a peace agreement that has ended the war in Bosnia. We hope that it will stay over with. Elections having just been held. There is great progress towards peace and reconciliation in Bosnia. We ought to be very proud of our soldiers who have played such a critical role in bringing about this peace in Bosnia. It's not the only case where Bill Clinton has provided such leadership. We have restored democracy to Haiti
column10: with scarcely a shot being fired. We have seen movement towards reconciliation in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East. The Bible says there will always be wars and rumors of wars. As the President said the other night
column11: there will always be troubles in this ol' world
column12: but the United States of America can be counted on to provide the vision that the world looks for from the United States of America. Bill Clinton
column13: as President
column14: has provided that kind of leadership. We are more secure and stronger today because of Bill Clinton's handling of foreign policy.

column1: Bob Dole supported the deployment of troops in Bosnia
column2: but the problem with the foreign policy of this administration
column3: there is none. It is ambiguous
column4: it is contradictory. It is precipitous to go into Iraq with bombing before we had even consulted with our allies. To think that Sam Nunn of Georgia or Colin Powell helped put together the coalition in the Persian Gulf were not even consulted. It was not only precipitous
column5: it was a sign
column6: not of strength
column7: but of weakness. What's worse
column8: they declared victory. They've declared victory in every deployment. We've had more deployments in four years than any previous four years I can think of
column9: and I'm 61 years of age. It's unbelievable that ambiguity can be called foreign policy. Let me say what a friend told me
column10: and I believed it for my whole career
column11: weakness is provocative and our message should be clear. And that's what our message would be to the world under Bob Dole as Commander-in-Chief of the United States of America.

column2: of course
column3: consult with our allies before we bombed Saddam Hussein
column4: but sometimes the United States has to take unilateral action when our interests are at stake. General Schwarzkopf is in the audience tonight. We're awfully proud of the way he led our coalition
column5: organized under former President Bush. When the United States toward the repulsing of Saddam Hussein from Kuwait
column6: three times as he's tried to get out of that box
column7: Saddam Hussein has felt the sting of a swift
column8: certain response from the United States of America under President Bill Clinton.

column2: it was Bob Dole that suggested that there be a fact-finding commission. President Carter was on it. Colin Powell was on it. You cannot say
column3: in our opinion
column4: that Haiti is a great success. Clearly
column5: uh it was maybe the right thing to do
column6: but we did not go in with enough information. We caused problems in the first place by denying Caribbean countries and third-world countries a chance to trade freely in the United States. It causes economic problems and turmoil
column7: and then we turn around
column8: as we did in Mexico
column9: having to bail them out. We caused the problem in the first place
column10: and it cost us 20 to 50 billion to bail them out. Haiti is very ambiguous at best. We pray that democracy comes to Haiti
column11: but so far
column12: the message from Haiti is quite ambiguous
column13: notwithstanding the declaration of victory by this administration.

column2: I didn't hear anything wrong. The fact is
column3: we restored democracy to Haiti. When I say ""restored"" actually
column4: it's the first real democracy that Haiti has ever had. And it happened with scarcely any shots being fired. I was in the Oval Office the night when President Clinton dispatched our troops from Ft  Bragg. It was a tense moment. The planes were in the air and our negotiators were talking with the dictator down there. And when that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off
column5: he said
column6: let's get out of here. That's how it was done. It was one of the most deft uses of diplomacy and military force in combination that you will find anywhere in the annals of the history of this country. I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that
column7: and the result
column8: so far
column9: is excellent. And we hope and pray that it will remain that way.

column1: Many more results like Bosnia and Haiti and Mexico
column2: and the Middle East
column3: and we won't have much success. One of the most serious -- one of the most serious problems was the tremendous effort by this administration to force on Mexico a devaluation of their peso. The economy has dropped by almost 40 to 50 percent. Then we go in and bail them out. We caused the problem
column4: then we have to bail them out. We should have a foreign policy that's predicated upon trade
column5: on spreading democracy
column6: by giving people opportunities to trade freely with us
column7: and making sure that everybody recognizes a rule of the Golden Rule
column8: ""To do unto others to have them do unto you."" Diplomacy first
column9: and don't bomb before breakfast.

column2: that's not right. When Mr. Kemp started talking about the Golden Rule
column3: I thought he was going to talk about the gold standard again. That used to be an integral part of this so-called ""Supply Side Economics
column4: but it may be something else that he now agrees with Bob Dole on
column5: because Bob Dole voted to take us off the gold standard
column6: a wise vote in my opinion. Most -- all economists say that if we did that
column7: it would throw us into a deep recession or depression and put millions out of work
column8: but let me come directly to this question. No
column9: when there was a crisis involving the Mexican peso
column10: again
column11: President Bill Clinton showed bold and dynamic leadership. I want to hasten to add that Senator Bob Dole gave critical bipartisan support at the time. He agreed with the President. He supported the President. He said this is a wise move. He could not get a majority in the Senate
column12: and Speaker Gingrich could not get a majority in the house to go on record in support of it. So
column13: the President
column14: as presidents often have to do
column15: went alone and did the right thing. You know
column16: people said it was a big risk at that time. We've ended up making a $500 million profit. All of the loans have been paid back. We're using that $500 million to further reduce the deficit. It's come down 60 percent already. It's going down even more toward a balanced budget
column17: and this is helping.

column1: It's unbelievable that we could cause a drop in the standard of living of a friendly country like Mexico by nearly 40 to 50 percent. Unemployment goes up
column2: we send U.S. tax dollars and IMF monies to Mexico
column3: and we make a profit. At that level
column4: that is -- gives new meaning to the word ""profitability"" for U.S. foreign policy. The pain
column5: the suffering
column6: the unemployment
column7: the bankruptcies
column8: the loss of the standard of living
column9: the people who have had to come across the border of California
column10: Arizona
column11: New Mexico and Texas if that's our foreign policy for the third-world or Latin America
column12: I believe more than ever
column13: we have to elect a president who understands trade
column14: who understands honest money
column15: who understands private enterprise
column16: who understands democratic capitalism
column17: not socialism caused by the IMF and the Clinton administration.

column2: I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico. They managed their own monetary policy. Years ago
column3: we used to hear this phrase in American politics
column4: the ""Blame America First"" crowd. I never liked that phrase
column5: but if it was going to be applied today
column6: it would have to be applied to this statement. The United States of America shouldn't be blamed for the management of Mexico's monetary policy. We helped our neighbor in an hour of need
column7: and they survived. They're stronger. They're coming back. They paid us back
column8: and we got a dividend in the process.
