column1: President Bill Clinton promised to create 8 million jobs. He's created 10 and a half million new jobs. He's promised to cut the budget deficit in half. He has cut it by 60 percent. He promised to end welfare as we know it. He passed and signed the Welfare Reform Law. He has already moved 1.9 million people off the welfare rolls into good jobs. We've got a plan to move 1 million more off welfare during the next four years. He promised to implement the death penalty. We passed an anti-crime Bill that has 60 new death penalty provisions. He promised to pass a plan that would put 100
column2: 000 new police officers on the streets. It is law
column3: over the opposition of Senator Dole
column4: and 20
column5: 000 of them are already on the streets
column7: 000 of them have been funded already for here in Florida. We're ahead of schedule and we're going to get the additional 80
column8: 000 new police officers on the streets in the coming four years
column10: 000 of them are now already funded. That is a record of promises made and promises kept. He promised middle-income tax cuts. We've cut taxes for 15 million families and our plan to cut them for all middle income families has been waiting for action in the Congress for two full years. In the next four years
column11: we will pass it.

column2: to say that this is the best economy in 30 years just staggers the imagination. We have a growth rate of the last four years of about two and a half percent. My friend Al Gore says it  's better than the Reagan years. It isn't. But irrespective of whether he thinks it is or not means less than fact that this country cannot morally and socially and economically accept an economy running out the clock on the 20th Century. We're treading water. We have families that are hurting. We have people who are unemployed. We have people with no property. We have an administration that is demolishing public housing in our inner cities and not providing anything else but more public housing. Their solution to the inner city is more -- excuse the expression but it's true
column3: ""socialism."" It is not for the people. It is for the government to tell them where to live
column4: where to go to school. We need school choice. We need to privatize public housing
column5: we need to sell it to the residents
column6: we need to put enterprise zone into
column7: in
column8: America and need to lower the rates of taxation on labor
column9: capital and the factors of production. That'll happen under Bob Dole.

column1: We are demolishing the outdated projects that did not work and we're replacing them with new units that do work. And we have private vouchers so that individuals can choose for themselves where they live and we're selling these units to many of those who want to buy them. Mr. Kemp had a good idea when he advocated that years ago. He talked about it
column2: we did it
column3: and we're going to do a lot more of it
column4: if we have the opportunity with the help of the American people.

column3: 9)	" Civility
column4: responsibility
column5: racial reconciliation
column6: healing the wounds of our country has to be one of the greatest
column7: most singularly important goals for this country here on the edge of the 21st Century. How in the name of American democracy can we say to eastern Europe that democratic capitalism will work there if we can't make it work in East L.A. or East Harlem or East Palo Alto
column8: California? How can we tell South Africa and the new Mandela government that democracy and private property and limited government and the rule of law and civility will work there if it's not working in our own backyard here at home or the South Bronx? How can America go into the next century and leave so many people behind? ""USA Today
column9: just few weeks ago did a study. They said the affluent are doing very well in America
column10: the haves
column11: the have-nots and the poor are being left behind. It is a giant
column12: in my opinion
column13: zero sum game. Kind of like musical chairs when we were young boys and girls growing up. And it seemed like when the music stopped the big guy elbowed out the little guy from that last chair. That's not America folks. We need more chairs
column14: we need a bigger table
column15: we need a greater banquet. We need to create more wealth. We need to create more jobs and more access to credit and capital and educational choice and opportunity for any man or woman and child to be what God meant them to be
column16: not what Washington
column17: D.C. wants them to be.

column2: that throughout much of his career
column3: Jack Kemp has been a powerful and needed voice against the kind of coarseness and incivility that you refer to in the question. I think it's an extremely valuable service to have a voice within the Republican party who says we ought to be one nation. We ought to cross all of the racial and ethnic and cultural barriers. I think that is a very important message to deliver. And we ought to speak out against these violations of civility when they do occur. You asked about the incident involving Roberto Alomar. I won't hesitate to tell you what I think. I think he should have been severely disciplined
column4: suspended perhaps
column5: immediately. I don't understand why that action was not taken
column6: but the same could be said of so many incidents in all kinds of institutions in our society
column7: but I compliment Mr. Kemp for the leadership he has shown in moving us away from that kind of attitude.

column2: I thank you
column3: Al. I mean that very
column4: very sincerely
column5: but I'm trying to make a bigger point. That civility cannot return to our country unless every person feels that they have an equal shot at the American dream. That if you're born in this country to be a mezzo-soprano or a master carpenter or a school teacher
column6: like my daughter
column7: or a professional football quarterback
column8: nothing should be in your way. And removing those barriers is what Bob Dole is all about
column9: moving our country forward and leaving no one behind.

column1: I think that economics is one of the single most important parts of this problem. That's why we're focusing on tax credits
column2: to hire 1 million more people coming off welfare in the inner city. That's why we're focusing on an economic policy that has already created ten and a half million new jobs and is going to create millions more within the context
column3: again
column4: of a balanced budget that protects important programs. We have focused especially on the most distressed areas
column5: because we cannot leave anyone behind. Our empowerment zones and enterprise communities
column6: the tax credits that will encourage the formation of new businesses
column7: the new approach by the small business administration to get more loans out to individuals that have not had equal access to capital in the past. These are parts of the plan. Another part of it is the community development financial institutions. And the -- and the law that says deposits that are made in a community
column8: in the inner cities say
column9: should be kept in the community
column10: not entirely
column11: but some percentage of them should be kept there. That prevents that money being taken from the community and invested in some go-go investment on the other side of the world. And when they invest in the community
column12: they find that there's a better payback rate
column13: more small businesses are created and the community improves. That's happening in America today
column14: not fast enough
column15: but faster than before and we think we can accelerate it with our plan.

column1: There really is no separation between a strong community and a strong economy. And you can't have a strong economy without strong communities and strong families. The word ""economics"" in Greek came from the word family
column2: or law or custom of the family. A family without a job where both breadwinners are away from home and cannot spend time with their children or can't send the child to the school of their choice rather than just the choice of the federal bureaucracy
column3: cannot possibly be as strong as a family that has the nurture
column4: the love
column5: the dignity and the justice that goes along with one breadwinner
column6: a strong job
column7: and if that man or woman wants to work
column8: it's their choice
column9: not just to pay taxes. So we need both. We need strong commun -- we need strong schools
column10: we need schools that nurture the type of discipline and respect from teachers and parents. And Bob Dole wants to empower the public school districts and the teachers
column11: not the federal bureaucracy at the Department of Education.

column2: Senator Dole has said that he wants to abolish the Department of Education. He voted against the creation of Head Start. He vigorously opposed the Family and Medical Leave Act
column3: which was the first law that President Clinton signed as president. Now
column4: Senator Dole has suggested he would repeal the Family and Medical Leave Act if he had the chance if he was elected president. We believe in more educational opportunity and measures to strengthen families
column5: not restrict their access to education.

column1: I wouldn't have voted for it. It's in place. Their answer
column2: this administration to every single problem is another regulation and another tax. Clearly
column3: in America
column4: we need -- I am astounded to think that you can have a strong Family Leave Act or policy by a business if they're not making a profit. If there aren't a lot of jobs
column5: if there isn't the types of policies that will enhance the formation of the seed corn and the oxygen and the capital that would allow that company not only retain that profit but invest it. As I said earlier
column6: Dana Crist of Lancaster
column7: Pennsylvania who runs a small little manufacturing or distribution center in Lancaster
column8: said that she as an entrepreneur
column9: would start a whole new factory if the federal government would cut the cost of capital. She wants the capital gains rate reduced. And if
column10: to Al Gore and Bill Clinton that is somehow
column11: trickle-down economics. Tell that to Dana Crist
column12: tell it to Van Woods
column13: tell it to the men and women I met in South Central. Tell it to anybody who understands how to makes democratic capitalism work. I want to say it one more time. The real excitement of a Dole/Kemp Administration would be to get out of this current tax code that redistributes wealth and create a brand new system for the 21st Century that's pro-family
column14: pro-growth and stops the double
column15: triple and quadruple taxation of income from work
column16: savings
column17: investment and entrepreneurial risk taking in America.

column2: it was about Family and Medical Leave. Here's how it works. If you have a child who is critically ill or has been seriously injured and you have to stay with that child in the hospital
column3: some employers
column4: have said you can't take too much time off in spite of these circumstances. I personally know people who have been fired because they made the choice to be with their child. Don't tell me this doesn't happen. It happens all across the United States. But since Bill Clinton made this the first law he signed
column5: it has been use 12 million times by American families to reconcile the demands of work with the responsibilities to the family. We now want to extend it to PTA meetings and scheduled doctors appointments. It shouldn't be repealed. It ought to be extended. 75 percent of businesses who have been -- had experience with it say they like it. It works.

column2: it was here before Bill Clinton and it will be here after Bill Clinton. Senator Tsongas a good friend of Senator Gore
column3: Vice President Gore suggested that he was afraid his party was falling into the trap of loving the employee
column4: but hating the employer. You cannot love labor and hate employers. You cannot drive this wedge between workers and management. And businesses were providing family leave. They will continue. They should. They've got to make a profit and the tax on business
column5: capital
column6: labor and families is too high and it will -- we want to reduce that regulatory burden and that tax burden in a new Dole/Kemp Administration.

column2: '09Oct'
column3: 9)	" Civility
column4: responsibility
column5: racial reconciliation
column6: healing the wounds of our country has to be one of the greatest
column7: most singularly important goals for this country here on the edge of the 21st Century. How in the name of American democracy can we say to eastern Europe that democratic capitalism will work there if we can't make it work in East L.A. or East Harlem or East Palo Alto
column8: California? How can we tell South Africa and the new Mandela government that democracy and private property and limited government and the rule of law and civility will work there if it's not working in our own backyard here at home or the South Bronx? How can America go into the next century and leave so many people behind? ""USA Today
column9: just few weeks ago did a study. They said the affluent are doing very well in America
column10: the haves
column11: the have-nots and the poor are being left behind. It is a giant
column12: in my opinion
column13: zero sum game. Kind of like musical chairs when we were young boys and girls growing up. And it seemed like when the music stopped the big guy elbowed out the little guy from that last chair. That's not America folks. We need more chairs
column14: we need a bigger table
column15: we need a greater banquet. We need to create more wealth. We need to create more jobs and more access to credit and capital and educational choice and opportunity for any man or woman and child to be what God meant them to be
column16: not what Washington
column17: D.C. wants them to be.

column2: that throughout much of his career
column3: Jack Kemp has been a powerful and needed voice against the kind of coarseness and incivility that you refer to in the question. I think it's an extremely valuable service to have a voice within the Republican party who says we ought to be one nation. We ought to cross all of the racial and ethnic and cultural barriers. I think that is a very important message to deliver. And we ought to speak out against these violations of civility when they do occur. You asked about the incident involving Roberto Alomar. I won't hesitate to tell you what I think. I think he should have been severely disciplined
column4: suspended perhaps
column5: immediately. I don't understand why that action was not taken
column6: but the same could be said of so many incidents in all kinds of institutions in our society
column7: but I compliment Mr. Kemp for the leadership he has shown in moving us away from that kind of attitude.

column2: I thank you
column3: Al. I mean that very
column4: very sincerely
column5: but I'm trying to make a bigger point. That civility cannot return to our country unless every person feels that they have an equal shot at the American dream. That if you're born in this country to be a mezzo-soprano or a master carpenter or a school teacher
column6: like my daughter
column7: or a professional football quarterback
column8: nothing should be in your way. And removing those barriers is what Bob Dole is all about
column9: moving our country forward and leaving no one behind.

column1: I think that economics is one of the single most important parts of this problem. That's why we're focusing on tax credits
column2: to hire 1 million more people coming off welfare in the inner city. That's why we're focusing on an economic policy that has already created ten and a half million new jobs and is going to create millions more within the context
column3: again
column4: of a balanced budget that protects important programs. We have focused especially on the most distressed areas
column5: because we cannot leave anyone behind. Our empowerment zones and enterprise communities
column6: the tax credits that will encourage the formation of new businesses
column7: the new approach by the small business administration to get more loans out to individuals that have not had equal access to capital in the past. These are parts of the plan. Another part of it is the community development financial institutions. And the -- and the law that says deposits that are made in a community
column8: in the inner cities say
column9: should be kept in the community
column10: not entirely
column11: but some percentage of them should be kept there. That prevents that money being taken from the community and invested in some go-go investment on the other side of the world. And when they invest in the community
column12: they find that there's a better payback rate
column13: more small businesses are created and the community improves. That's happening in America today
column14: not fast enough
column15: but faster than before and we think we can accelerate it with our plan.

column1: There really is no separation between a strong community and a strong economy. And you can't have a strong economy without strong communities and strong families. The word ""economics"" in Greek came from the word family
column2: or law or custom of the family. A family without a job where both breadwinners are away from home and cannot spend time with their children or can't send the child to the school of their choice rather than just the choice of the federal bureaucracy
column3: cannot possibly be as strong as a family that has the nurture
column4: the love
column5: the dignity and the justice that goes along with one breadwinner
column6: a strong job
column7: and if that man or woman wants to work
column8: it's their choice
column9: not just to pay taxes. So we need both. We need strong commun -- we need strong schools
column10: we need schools that nurture the type of discipline and respect from teachers and parents. And Bob Dole wants to empower the public school districts and the teachers
column11: not the federal bureaucracy at the Department of Education.

column2: Senator Dole has said that he wants to abolish the Department of Education. He voted against the creation of Head Start. He vigorously opposed the Family and Medical Leave Act
column3: which was the first law that President Clinton signed as president. Now
column4: Senator Dole has suggested he would repeal the Family and Medical Leave Act if he had the chance if he was elected president. We believe in more educational opportunity and measures to strengthen families
column5: not restrict their access to education.

column1: I wouldn't have voted for it. It's in place. Their answer
column2: this administration to every single problem is another regulation and another tax. Clearly
column3: in America
column4: we need -- I am astounded to think that you can have a strong Family Leave Act or policy by a business if they're not making a profit. If there aren't a lot of jobs
column5: if there isn't the types of policies that will enhance the formation of the seed corn and the oxygen and the capital that would allow that company not only retain that profit but invest it. As I said earlier
column6: Dana Crist of Lancaster
column7: Pennsylvania who runs a small little manufacturing or distribution center in Lancaster
column8: said that she as an entrepreneur
column9: would start a whole new factory if the federal government would cut the cost of capital. She wants the capital gains rate reduced. And if
column10: to Al Gore and Bill Clinton that is somehow
column11: trickle-down economics. Tell that to Dana Crist
column12: tell it to Van Woods
column13: tell it to the men and women I met in South Central. Tell it to anybody who understands how to makes democratic capitalism work. I want to say it one more time. The real excitement of a Dole/Kemp Administration would be to get out of this current tax code that redistributes wealth and create a brand new system for the 21st Century that's pro-family
column14: pro-growth and stops the double
column15: triple and quadruple taxation of income from work
column16: savings
column17: investment and entrepreneurial risk taking in America.

column2: it was about Family and Medical Leave. Here's how it works. If you have a child who is critically ill or has been seriously injured and you have to stay with that child in the hospital
column3: some employers
column4: have said you can't take too much time off in spite of these circumstances. I personally know people who have been fired because they made the choice to be with their child. Don't tell me this doesn't happen. It happens all across the United States. But since Bill Clinton made this the first law he signed
column5: it has been use 12 million times by American families to reconcile the demands of work with the responsibilities to the family. We now want to extend it to PTA meetings and scheduled doctors appointments. It shouldn't be repealed. It ought to be extended. 75 percent of businesses who have been -- had experience with it say they like it. It works.

column2: it was here before Bill Clinton and it will be here after Bill Clinton. Senator Tsongas a good friend of Senator Gore
column3: Vice President Gore suggested that he was afraid his party was falling into the trap of loving the employee
column4: but hating the employer. You cannot love labor and hate employers. You cannot drive this wedge between workers and management. And businesses were providing family leave. They will continue. They should. They've got to make a profit and the tax on business
column5: capital
column6: labor and families is too high and it will -- we want to reduce that regulatory burden and that tax burden in a new Dole/Kemp Administration.
